awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated Field and Laboratory Based Assessment of Liquefaction Triggering and Residual Strength of Gravelly Soil
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the leading causes of damage during earthquakes is soil liquefaction.  Liquefaction causes loose soil to behave more like a heavy liquid than a solid which can result in settlement of buildings as well as landslides and dam failures.  Recently, extensive gravel liquefaction and damage was observed in the 2008 Wenchuan, China, earthquake and the 2014 Cephalonia, Greece, earthquake sequences, and the evidence indicates that gravelly soils that were considered non-liquefiable using existing liquefaction susceptibility methods, did liquefy.  This study will provide a fundamental understanding, as well as practical guidance on assessing whether a gravel deposit will liquefy.  Such deposits are encountered widely and their potential liquefaction is commonly a critical consideration in the stability of our nation's ports, dams, levees and in general, civil infrastructure.  The improved procedures that will be developed will enhance the resiliency of these facilities, and will help in avoiding unnecessary expenses when gravel liquefaction is not really an issue, or more importantly, highlight the need for stabilization when gravel liquefaction is indeed expected.  The research team will establish a web-site with a gravel liquefaction database, and document all available case histories of gravel liquefaction. Videos on the mechanism of liquefaction that can be used for outreach purposes will be developed, as well as a recorded webinar and other educational resources on the outcomes of this study with emphasis on the recommended procedures for liquefaction assessment of gravelly soils. 

Characterization of gravelly soils in a reliable, cost-effective manner for routine engineering projects remains a challenge and methods such as the Cone Penetration Test and Standard Penetration Test are not considered appropriate.  Even for large projects, such as dams and energy projects, characterization is expensive (if Becker testing is used) and problematic. Nevertheless, because liquefaction is known to have occurred in gravelly soils in a significant number of earthquakes, dam engineers are frequently called upon to assess the potential for liquefaction in gravels and liquefaction mitigation costs often run into millions of dollars.  With the majority of research in soil liquefaction engineering focused on the assessment of the likelihood of "triggering" of liquefaction in sands and silty soils, new approaches, and transformative methods for characterizing gravels are needed.  In this collaborative project, there is a coordinated plan that combines unique large scale laboratory testing and innovative field testing at key gravel liquefaction sites to develop liquefaction triggering charts and post-liquefaction shear strength recommendations for gravelly soils.  A prototype 300-mm diameter cyclic simple shear (CSS) device has been developed at the University of Michigan and will be used to evaluate the cyclic (and monotonic) undrained shear response of gravelly soils in the laboratory.  A next-generation dynamic cone penetration test (DPT) that was originally developed in China will be modernized with key instrumentation and will be used for field testing along with in-situ shear wave velocity (Vs) measurements.  Field testing will be conducted in the USA, China, and Greece, leveraging resources from international partners, in-situ testing firms and organizations.  The PIs will leverage well-documented case studies of gravel liquefaction in the recent Cephalonia earthquake to validate the new methods and augment the field performance record of gravel liquefaction.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Civil & Env. Eng. Dept., Brigham Young Univ

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Liquefaction of loose saturated soil results in significant damage to buildings, bridges, dams, roadways, pipelines, and ports in nearly every earthquake. While liquefaction (transformation of solid soil to a liquid state) has commonly been observed in sand layers, gravel layers have also liquefied in more than 25 earthquakes over the past 130 years. Engineers have developed procedures to predict liquefaction in sand layers, but these procedures are not reliable in gravel layers. Existing techniques for predicting liquefaction in gravel are expensive and not readily available throughout the world. In this study, two new methods have been developed to predict liquefaction in gravels. Both methods are simple, economically viable, and easy to implement in engineering practice. To develop these new approaches, it was necessary to perform tests or collect existing test results from field sites where gravels had or had not liquefied in past earthquakes. Working with colleagues throughout the world, we obtained test results from over 150 sites in 10 countries. We performed tests in Idaho and Alaska in the US as well as in China, Taiwan, Italy, Greece, New Zealand, Ecuador, Chile, and Japan. These tests were then used to develop criteria for when gravels would and would not liquefy based on the magnitude and acceleration of the earthquake. These new prediction approaches represent a significant step forward relative to previous indirect approaches which were not based on actual field case histories. Our investigations found that gravels are most susceptible to liquefaction when they contain 20 to 30% sand size particles within the gravel. The results of this research have been widely publicized to the engineering community by 10 peer-reviewed journal articles and 6 conference papers. We have also given presentations on the research at conferences, seminars, and meetings throughout the world.

 Liquefaction assessment in gravels is particularly important for older dams that were constructed on gravelly soil or with poorly compacted gravel shells before the potential for liquefaction in gravels was recognized. Likewise, many ports around the world were constructed of gravelly soils or rockfill which was believed to be immune to liquefaction. For these projects, assessing the potential for liquefaction and determining appropriate remedial measures are often multi-million-dollar decisions. These decisions involve both life-safety and regional economic issues. Our new assessment techniques have been well received by engineers dealing with gravel liquefaction at ports in Wellington, New Zealand; Iquique, Chile; Manta, Ecuador; and Cephalonia, Greece. Likewise, engineers at the US Army Corps of Engineers and the US Bureau of Reclamation, who have responsibility for dam safety in the US, have been happy about the development of these new liquefaction assessment methods for gravel. They are now working with us to conduct additional research to further improve these methods. This study also provided an opportunity for one student to earn his Ph.D. degree while another student earned a master’s degree. In addition, several undergraduate students traveled with our team to Italy and Alaska where they learned to perform the new field tests we developed to identify liquefiable gravels. Because of this exposure, these students decided to continue on for graduate study.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Kyle M Rollins
